channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Cambridge Analytica Had a Role in Kenya Election, Too
item.media:description: Supporters greeting President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya, center, during a rally in Nairobi last year. Cambridge Analytica played a critical role in Mr. Kenyatta’s campaign.
item.description: An undercover video broadcast on British television revealed that the company worked for the re-election of President Uhuru Kenyatta.
item.dc:creator: JINA MOORE

item.title: In Nafta Talks, U.S. Tries to Limit Junk Food Warning Labels
item.media:description: Mexicans drink on average more than 44 gallons of soda a year per person. A family shopping at a supermarket in San Cristóbal de las Casas, in Chiapas, last year.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: A Trump administration proposal would limit the ability of Mexico, Canada and the U.S. to warn consumers about the dangers of foods linked to obesity.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, MATT RICHTEL and ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: Office of the United States Trade Representative

item.title: South Korea’s Leader Floats 3-Way Talks With Trump and Kim Jong-un
item.media:description: A TV at a railway station in Seoul, the South Korean capital, showing, from left, President Trump, President Moon Jae-in of South Korea and Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader.
item.description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea said he hoped that after he and President Trump met separately with Mr. Kim, the three leaders could sit down together.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Cambridge Analytica Suspends C.E.O. Amid Facebook Data Scandal
item.media:description: Alexander Nix, the chief executive of the London-based political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica, left his offices through the back door on Tuesday.
item.description: The company’s board said it was suspending the chief executive, Alexander Nix, with immediate effect, pending an independent investigation.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Fearing New Outbreaks, Brazil Will Vaccinate Country Against Yellow Fever
item.media:description: Health workers visited the Pirituba neighborhood of São Paulo this month to vaccinate residents.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: The measure comes after health officials had declared an outbreak last year contained. Yet, more than 300 people have died from the virus this year.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: China’s New ‘Helmsman’ Offers a Strident Nationalist Message
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping’s speech on Tuesday, the last day of the National People’s Congress in Beijing, was a final flourish in a spectacle that has emphasized his supremacy. “Miracles are constantly emerging across this great land of China,” he said.
item.description: President Xi Jinping’s speech on the last day of the National People’s Congress in Beijing was heavy on patriotism and underscored his dominance.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Russia, a Founder of a Chemical Arms Watchdog, Is Now in Its Cross Hairs
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin during a video conference in September 2017, when he was said to order the destruction of the last chemical weapons stored in Russia.
item.description: Six months ago, chemical weapons experts celebrated Russia’s disarmament. Now they are investigating Britain’s allegation of a secret weapons program.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons

item.title: Beijing Journal: A Beijing Bookstore Where George Washington Is on the Shelves
item.media:description: The All Sages Bookstore in Beijing “is a way to express our longing for freedom and our hope for the establishment of a free society,” its owner says.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: All Sages Bookstore, run by a onetime Tiananmen protester, has survived the capital’s ferocious property market and the censorship of the Xi Jinping era.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Kabul Suicide Bombing Kills 26 in Holiday Crowd, Officials Say
item.media:description: Victims’ bodies at a hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, after the suicide bombing of a crowd celebrating Nowruz, the Persian New Year, on Wednesday.
item.description: Dozens in a crowd celebrating Nowruz, the Persian New Year, were killed by a bombing near a Shiite shrine in the western part of the Afghan capital.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Where Do Birds Flock Together? Australians Are Mailing In Feathers to Help Find Out
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.description: Kate Brandis, an Australian researcher, has enlisted the public to help her track elusive waterfowl as the country’s wetlands disappear.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA

item.title: James Packer, Australian Billionaire, Resigns From Casino Company
item.media:description: James Packer “intends to step back from all commitments,” his investment company said.
item.description: Mr. Packer, one of Australia’s richest men, recently found himself embroiled in a corruption scandal involving Israel’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: FedEx, Facebook, Iraq: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Canada Plans to Tighten Gun Reviews and Records
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaking in the House of Commons on Tuesday. “We’re taking action for common-sense gun control,” he said on Twitter, “while protecting the rights of law-abiding gun owners.”
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s government proposed legislation to restore record-keeping requirements for long-gun sales and expand background checks for gun owners.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: A Town Quebec Would Rather Forget: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Hérouxville has one set of traffic lights, a post office, a church and a dépanneur, or convenience store.
item.description: Dan Bilefsky’s road trip takes him to Hérouxville, where a code of conduct for immigrants issued 10 years ago is still a sore subject.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: BMW Offices Raided by Authorities in Emissions-Cheating Investigation
item.media:description: The German carmaker BMW’s headquarters in Munich. Prosecutors searched the offices on Tuesday for evidence that some of the company’s cars had evaded emissions controls.
item.description: Munich prosecutors targeted BMW’s headquarters in search of evidence of possible emissions cheating, further tarnishing the reputation of German carmakers.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Cropped Cuts for Everyone
item.media:description: At Barberette, a gender-neutral salon with locations in Prague and London, there’s no “men’s price” for a short haircut. The cost of a cropped do is the same for everyone.
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.description: At Barberette, Klara Vanova offers a catalog of hairstyles that renounce gender conformity.
item.dc:creator: PHILIP J. HEIJMANS

item.title: What’s in a Name? For Macedonia, the Key to Peace and Security
item.media:description: A statue of Alexander the Great in Skopje, the capital of Macedonia. The government of Greece also lays claim to the leader’s history.
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.description: The Balkan country has been blocked from joining NATO and the European Union by Greece, which for decades has fought to keep the name Macedonia for itself.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: Trump Congratulates Putin, but Doesn’t Mention Meddling in U.S.
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was re-elected this week.
item.description: “We had a very good call,” President Trump told reporters in the Oval Office after speaking with the Russian leader after his re-election. “We will probably be meeting in the not-too-distant future.”
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Norway’s Justice Minister Resigns in Storm Over Facebook Post
item.media:description: The Norwegian justice minister, Sylvi Listhaug, accused the country’s Labor Party of “protecting terrorists over citizens.” Norway’s worst terrorist attack of modern times, in 2011, targeted Labor members.
item.media:credit: Hakon Mosvold Larsen/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.description: The post by the right-wing minister, Sylvi Listhaug, revived memories of a 2011 terrorist attack and stirred a controversy that threatened the coalition government.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL and RICHARD MARTYN-HEMPHILL

item.title: The Last Male Northern White Rhino Is Gone
item.description: The 45-year-old Sudan, the sole remaining male of the rare subspecies of white rhino, died in Kenya.

item.title: A Glimpse of a Crown Prince’s Dream? Saudi Arabia Invades Iran in CGI
item.description: An animated video depicts the kingdom’s forces under Mohammed bin Salman marching into Tehran as conquering heroes. Is it serious or a satire?
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Nigeria Failed to Act in Schoolgirl Kidnappings by Boko Haram, Report Says
item.media:description: A classroom at the school in Dapchi, Nigeria, where dozens of school girls were kidnapped by Boko Haram militants last month.
item.description: Amnesty International accused security forces of doing nothing despite warnings that the militants were nearby. The military denounced the group’s findings.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and EMMANUEL AKINWOTU

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy, Ex-President of France, Is Held for Questioning on Libyan Cash
item.media:description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, left, welcomed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya to the Élysée Palace in 2007.
item.description: Mr. Sarkozy is facing an investigation into whether his 2007 election campaign received funding from the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: ‘At War,’ The Times’s Renegade Blog From the Front Lines, Returns
item.media:description: American soldiers in Kunduz, Afghanistan, in October 2010.
item.description: On the 15th anniversary of the U.S. invasion of Iraq, The Times reintroduces At War, a forum for the firsthand experiences of global conflict.
item.dc:creator: LARA TAKENAGA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Do You Get 200,000 Pounds of Trash Off Everest? Recruit Yaks.
item.media:description: Workers loading garbage collected from the Everest region at the airport in Lukla, Nepal, from which it will be flown to Kathmandu for recycling. Porters and yaks ferry the trash on their backs from a string of villages leading up to Everest base camp.
item.description: Nepal has begun an ambitious waste management project aimed at “saving the glory of the Everest region” from trekkers’ garbage.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: World Economic Leaders Warn of Trade War as Mnuchin Defends Policies
item.media:description: Steven Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, on Tuesday at a meeting of the Group of 20 finance ministers and central bankers in Buenos Aires.
item.description: As global finance ministers gather in Argentina, the United States’ protectionist position on trade has consumed the discussions.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: At War: 15 Years Ago, I Helped Start a War That Hasn’t Ended
item.media:description: Preparing for war: Marine Corps reservists from Syracuse, N.Y., working on their Abrams M1-A1 tank as a “Jolly Roger” flies from the radio antenna of another tank on Feb. 16, 2003, at U.S.M.C. Camp Grizzly in the northern Kuwaiti desert near Iraq.
item.description: As the United States enters its 15th year of war in Iraq, a former Marine Corps tanker remembers the invasion that set the occupation, and all its destruction, in motion.
item.dc:creator: MATT UFFORD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: International Herald Tribune: 1893: Arrest of a Suspected German Spy
item.media:description: An officer in the German Army was arrested and imprisoned on suspicion of being a spy.
item.description: An officer in the German Army was arrested in Rouen, after suspicions arose that he was working there as a spy.
item.dc:creator: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: A Saudi War With Iran? It’s a Cartoon, for Now
item.description: An animated video published by an anonymous pro-Saudi-government group makes a point of showing off the kingdom’s arsenal in an imagined invasion of its regional nemesis, Iran. Some say they believe Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is behind it.

item.title: ‘We’re Losing the Fight’: Tuberculosis Batters a Venezuela in Crisis
item.media:description: Pallbearers carried the coffin of Victor Martínez, 47, who died of tuberculosis last month in Petare, Venezuela.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The disease, which until recently seemed to be under control in Venezuela, is making an aggressive comeback in the nation, overwhelming its broken health care system.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Profiles in Science: David Reich Unearths Human History Etched in Bone
item.media:description: Jonas Oppenheimer, a technician in the lab of David Reich, a geneticist at Harvard, sandblasts an ancient skull fragment to find the cochlea, or inner ear, the area likeliest to retain DNA.
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.description: The geneticist at Harvard Medical School has retrieved DNA from more than 900 ancient people. His findings trace the prehistoric migrations of our species.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Five Important Takeaways From China’s National People’s Congress
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping taking the oath of office on Saturday after being re-elected in a landslide, at a meeting of China’s largely ceremonial National People’s Congress.
item.description: Lawmakers revoked term limits for Xi Jinping and made other changes that will shape China for years. Here’s how The Times covered the annual session.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What’s Next for Humanity: Automation, New Morality and a ‘Global Useless Class’
item.description: In an event organized by The New York Times and How To Academy, the historian and author Yuval Noah Harari offered his predictions for the future.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Yuval Noah Harari on the Future of Humanity
item.description: Humans, Mr. Harari warned, “have created such a complicated world that we’re no longer able to make sense of what is happening.”

item.title: U.S. and South Korea to Resume Joint Military Exercises
item.media:description: South Korean marines during joint exercises with the United States in April 2017.
item.description: On April 1, the countries will resume the annual drills that they suspended during the Olympics and Paralympics, the Pentagon announced Monday.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Soldier in Bloody Niger Mission Had Warned of Gaps, Defense Officials Say
item.media:description: The coffin of Sgt. La David Johnson, one of four American soldiers killed during an ambush in Niger last year, was moved after a viewing in Cooper City, Fla., in October.
item.description: Pentagon leaders are said to be troubled by draft conclusions of an inquiry that blames low-level officers in an ambush that killed four American troops.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER, THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How the Ambush of U.S. Soldiers in Niger Unfolded
item.description: One of the American soldiers ambushed by militants in Niger was wearing a helmet camera – we analyzed the footage to understand what happened.

item.title: Driving With Assad: Syria’s President Tours a Destroyed Suburb
item.media:description: Government airstrikes hit eastern Ghouta on Monday.
item.description: As his soldiers wage a brutal offensive near Damascus, President Bashar al-Assad takes a leisurely drive into the heart of the civil war.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: White House Bans Venezuela’s Digital Currency and Expands Sanctions
item.media:description: The sanctions were intended to send a message to Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, that the United States holds him directly responsible for his country’s economic devastation, the White House said.
item.description: The Trump administration also blacklisted four associates of President Nicolás Maduro, pressuring a government it has accused of graft and repression.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: Cambridge Analytica, Trump, Cynthia Nixon: Your Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ZACH JOHNK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Assad Takes Driving Tour of Eastern Ghouta
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria appeared in a series of videos driving from Damascus to eastern Ghouta, the suburb that has been under siege for almost five years.

item.title: Russia Credits the West for Putin’s Big Victory
item.media:description: At the Kremlin on Monday, President Vladimir V. Putin, left, met with the opposition candidates who ran against him in the presidential election: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, shaking hands with the president; Pavel N. Grudinin; and Sergei Baburin, right.
item.description: Officials said Western pressure had galvanized “the consolidation and unification” of support for the Russian president in Sunday’s presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Russian Election: Videos Show Possible Fraud
item.description: Election observers and opposition activists shared videos on social media showing individuals appearing to cast multiple ballots during Russia’s election on Sunday.

item.title: Drawn to a Cause, British Woman Dies Fighting Alongside Kurds in Syria
item.media:description: Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army soldiers celebrated after capturing the city of Afrin in northern Syria from Kurdish forces known as the People’s Protection Units, or Y.P.G., on Sunday.
item.description: Anna Campbell, 26, was the eighth Briton, and the first British woman, to be killed fighting for Kurdish-led forces in Syria’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Ban on Face Veils at Indonesian University Lasted Just a Week
item.media:description: In banning full niqab head coverings at Sunan Kalijaga State Islamic University this month, its rector said they were not a natural part of Indonesian culture. After days of protests, he dropped the ban.
item.description: Protests led an Islamic university to reverse its ban on niqabs, a move that advocates of moderate Islam see as a troubling sign.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: French Consulate Worker Is Accused of Smuggling Guns From Gaza
item.media:description: Romain Franck, face covered, an employee of the French Consulate in Jerusalem, at a court in Beersheba, Israel, on Monday.
item.description: The charges came after a weekend in which three people were killed in two attacks, and as Israelis braced for more violence in the Palestinian territories.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Mighty Women Warriors, Resurrected From an Ancient Epic
item.media:description: A rehearsal of “Forty Girls” in Tashkent, Uzbekistan. The musical retells an ancient epic of female warriors in Central Asia who resisted male invaders, fighting to the death rather than submit to the victors.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The new telling of “Forty Girls,” which mixes video, songs and traditional and modern music, is a bold departure for a Muslim country, especially Uzbekistan.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: U.K. Reaches Brexit Transition Deal With E.U.
item.media:description: David Davis, Britain’s chief negotiator, left, and Michel Barnier, his European Union counterpart, in Brussels on Monday. The two announced a conditional deal on a transition period after Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union, though Mr. Barnier warned, “Nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.”
item.description: The two sides have negotiated a 21-month transition period after the withdrawal next March. But the deal depends on a solution to the Irish border question.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
